features.title: What is Baby Feeding Code Square?
features.text_1: Breast milk provides antibodies that give babies everywhere a healthy boost and protect them against many infections. Antibodies and bioactive factors in breast milk may fight against COVID-19 infection if the baby is exposed. In addition, the corona virus has not been found in breast milk, and transmission via breastfeeding has not been demonstrated.
features.text_2: Based on global WHO/UNICEF guidelines and nationally recommended feeding practices, it is important to:
features.feature_1_text: Initiate breastfeeding within 1 hour of birth. Maintain skin-to-skin contact with your baby, which will keep your baby warm and breathing well, help him or she reach the breast easily, and help you and your baby feel close.
features.feature_2_text: Close contact and early, exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months helps a baby to thrive, and the unparalleled benefits of breastfeeding outweigh any potential risk of transmission. Breast Milk is the best healthy first food for your baby and is sufficient to support your child’s healthy growth and development.
features.feature_3_text: Introduce age-appropriate, adequate, safe and properly fed complementary foods starting from 6 months up to 2 years of age (see examples and guidance in complementary feeding section)
features.feature_4_text: Continue breastfeeding for up to 2 years of age or beyond.
features.text_3: In view of the vulnerability of infants in the early months of life and the risks involved in inappropriate feeding practices, including unnecessary and improper use of breast milk substitutes, the marketing of breast milk substitutes requires special treatment, which makes usual marketing practices unsuitable for these products.

violation.title: What is a Violation?
violation.section_1_text: A follow-up formula is marketed or otherwise represented to be suitable, with or without modification, or used as a partial or total replacement for breast milk, it is covered by the Code. In addition, where followup formula is otherwise represented in a manner that results in such product being perceived or used as a partial or total replacement for breastmilk, such product also falls within the scope of the Code.
violation.section_2_text: The resolution recommends breastfeeding to continue for up to 2 years or beyond. Any milk product that is marketed or represented as suitable as a partial or total replacement of the breast milk part of the young child is a breastmilk substitute and is in the scope. The words “or beyond” could be interpreted to mean young children up to 3 years as there is no upper age limit to the definition of “breastmilk substitute”.
violation.section_3_text:
Regardless of age indication, any product that is recommended to be fed through a feeding bottle falls under the scope of the International Code as bottle-feeding undermines breastfeeding. To determine whether the product is a bottle-fed complimentary food, ask the following questions:
  • Is the product recommended to be fed by a feeding bottle?
  • Does the label show a feeding bottle?
violation.section_4_title: Violation 4 iv. Any food or beverage that is represented as suitable to be fed to infants less than 6 months old.
violation.section_4_text:
Regardless of the age indication on labels, products that are recommended for use by infants when they reach a specific stage of development which normally occurs before 6 months should also be considered to be breastmilk substitutes.
The following questions will help to determine if a product is so represented.
  • Does the label say as of 4 months or 5 months or earlier?
  • Do the instructions indicate how to feed infants younger than 6 months or show an infant obviously younger than 6 months?
  • Does the label or other materials include phrases such as “from the start”, “first stage” or suggest that a child is “ready for his first food” as he reached a certain development milestone that normally appears before a child reaches 6 months? For example, “lifting his neck and head”, “putting his hand in his mouth” or “smiles back at you” are stages infants arrive at well before 6 months.
  • Does the label say “as of the 6th month”? Or does it say “as of 6 months?”
violation.section_5_text:
• there is no impediment for products covered by the scope to be sold. The International Code is designed only to stop companies from promoting their products.
  • we are dealing with public health recommendations and marketing controls, not with obliging individual mothers to breastfeed.

policy.title: Privacy Policy
policy.section_1_text: We collect information from you when you want to report any    adherence and or violations of the International Code of Marketing of Breast-Milk Substitutes. Such information may include impersonal information about your use of the website. We do not capture any personal information about you when you access this website or the chatbot.

policy.section_2_text:
We implement a variety of security measures to maintain the safety of your personal information when you enter, submit, or access your personal information.
We offer the use of a secure server. All supplied information is transmitted via Secure Socket Layer (SSL) technology.
policy.section_3_text:

policy.section_4_text:
The information that is transmitted through or stored on RapidPro or Bothub is only available for helping to track rumours and improve the chatbot based upon your feedback.
Note that any messages transmitted via social media channels may be accessible by certain third-party organizations, such as cellular service providers used to transmit the messages. These organizations may have their own rules, policies, and security measures controlling who has access to messages transmitted through their services.

policy.section_5_text: We do not sell, trade, or otherwise transfer to outside parties your personally identifiable information. This does not include trusted third parties who assist us in operating our website, conducting our business, or servicing you, so long as those parties agree to keep this information confidential. We may also release your information when we believe release is appropriate to comply with the law, enforce our site policies, or protect ours or others’ rights, property, or safety. However, non-personally identifiable visitor information may be provided to other parties for marketing, advertising, or other uses.
policy.section_6_text: Occasionally, at our discretion, we may include or offer third-party products or services on our website. These third-party sites have separate and independent privacy policies. We therefore have no responsibility or liability for the content and activities of these linked sites. Nonetheless, we seek to protect the integrity of our site and welcome any feedback about these sites.
